subject: Re: [junit] Private method throws an exception
msgSnippet: ... If you re going to use the debugger, then you don t need to write that smaller test. Agreed. I simply prefer not to use the debugger if I don t have to.
messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > If you have a failing test, but you aren't sure why it fails, and you
> > suspect the problem is in a private method, what do you generally do?
>
> If I have a failing test that fails because an exception is thrown out
> of a private method, I debug it. First off I eyeball the code both in
> the private method and the public method being tested. Most of the time
> the reason for the failure is obvious. If it's not, I'll generally set a
> breakpoint or two and step through the code in the debugger and watch
> what actually happens. This is a lot more productive than guessing at
> what the problem might be. If I could guess right, then I wouldn't need
> to step through it.

If you're going to use the debugger, then you don't need to write that
smaller test. Agreed. I simply prefer not to use the debugger if I don't
have to. It's part of me continuing to practise writing good tests.

<snip />

> If the bug proves to be deep inside another piece of code, then I might
> later add a second test that aims more closely at the bug. However,
> that's only done after I've identified the bug, and often I don't even
> bother to do that. After all, there's already at least one test for the
> issue.

That's fine. I simply aim for smaller tests, and whenever a test fails
and I can't pinpoint the problem, I generally aim to introduce a smaller
test. If not, then I'd tend towards too many big tests, combinatoric
explosion and all that.

Even if I do have to step through code with a debugger, I generally want
to use that as a way to find out what input combination I didn't test in
one of my methods, so I can add that test.

Thanks for giving me a look inside your personal process. It helps me
understand your point of view, even though I still disagree with "it
doesn't solve the problem," since I obviously /do/ solve problems that way.

Take care.
